intro: Orobanche ludoviciana var. arenosa, commonly known as the desert broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a taproot system that allows it to anchor itself to its host. It is often found growing on the roots of native grasses and forbs, and it plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have significant impacts on the growth and survival of its host plants.
